title: 1%2C800 people on list for housing
story: THE enormity of the districtrsquos social housing crisis has been revealed this week.New figures published by the Housing Executive confirm that there are currently , people on the waiting list for public sector housing across Down District, with demand continuing to outstrip supply.Almost  per cent of those on the waiting list mdash , mdash are classed in the urgent need category, with the need particularly high in Downpatrick and Newcastle.Up until the end of March,  people had been allocated homes in Down District over the previous  months. The figure for the entire Newry, Mourne and Down Council area is .Housing chiefs confirmed that during the last financial year,  homes were completed across the local authority area and at the end of March,  new social homes were under construction, with plans to start work on building  more over the next three years.Homelessness also continues to be a major issue across the council area with , people not having a permanent home and Covid- being blamed on exacerbating this particular situation.During a special briefing session with councillors on Monday night, senior Housing Executive officials provided a detailed overview of the current waiting list and homelessness situation as they outlined details of the organisationrsquos work over the past  months and its future plans.They revealed that single, older persons and small family households comprise the majority of social housing applicants in the urgent need category across the district.Politicians say they are very aware of the need for more social housing and that the issue is the one most frequently raised with them by people from every corner of the district.Across the entire Newry, Mourne and Down Council area, there are currently , people on the waiting list for homes, with , in urgent need. The figures represent an increase of  and  respectively on the previous  months.Locally, the current waiting list figures reveal that  people are seeking social homes in Downpatrick, with  in the so-called urgent need category.In Newcastle, where a number of potential development sites have been identied,  people are on the waiting list, with  in urgent need. Last year, the number of homes allocated in both towns was  and  respectively.In Ballynahinch, there are  applicants on the waiting list, with  in the urgent need category.In the Castlewellan and Drumaroad area,  people are seeking homes, with  in urgent need, while there are  people on the waiting list for homes in Killyleagh and  in urgent need.In the Crossgar and Annacloy area,  people are on the waiting list with  in the urgent need bracket. Seventy three people are seeking social housing in the Ardglass, Ballyhornan and Dunsford area with  in urgent need, while in Saintfield  people are on the waiting list for a home with  in urgent need.In the Clough area, which includes Dundrum and Seaforde,  people are seeking social housing with  in urgent need, while  people are on the waiting list for a home in Strangford and Kilclief with the vast majority mdash  mdash in urgent need.The Housing Executive has confirmed that  people are on the waiting list for a home in Drumaness, with  classed in the urgent need category, while in Killough,  people are on the waiting list with  classed in urgent need, with  people seeking a home in Kilcoo. It was also confirmed that less than  people are on the waiting list for social housing in Annsborough, Shrigley, Kilmore and Spa areas.Addressing councillors on Monday evening, Housing Executive chief executive Grainia Long reflected on an ldquounprecedented year and said that Covid- had presented ldquohuge challenges for the organisation.She said staff moved staff out of offices to work at home, while lockdown restrictions and supply issues meant a backlog in tacking repairs and delays in much-needed upgrade schemes on estates.She said almost poundm was invested in new-build accommodation in the district, which saw  housing starts getting underway, while housing completions for the year were , despite the pandemic.She continued: ldquoWe provided pound, in grant funding to support local groups in Newry, Mourne and Down, across several funding streams, including our community grants, community safety, areas at risk and community cohesion programmes. We also supported  people experiencing homelessness in the last year.ldquoGiven the necessity to social distance the hostels in Newry, Mourne and Down, this situation placed enormous pressure on temporary accommodation in the district and as we emerge from the pandemic, our reset plan, The Way Home, has been fully funded by the Department for Communities..prettyPhoto

title: Ardglass chemist Paula retires after 31 years
story: AN Ardglass woman has bid an emotional farewell to the community ahead of her retirement after  years of service in the area.Paula McDaid, owner of McDaidrsquos Chemist, hosted a marquee reception last week as a thank you to her many loyal customers.Paula says although it has not been an easy decision the time is now right for her to retire from the business and move on.ldquoI want to thank my customers, for their loyalty and support throughout my  years as the pharmacist in Ardglass, she said.ldquoItrsquos been an amazing journey with a lot of laughs, meeting many colourful and ied characters who I have built up relationships with along the way.ldquoIt was lovely to see everyone at the marquee and Irsquom so thankful for their kind comments and well wishes.She added: ldquoI also wish to extend thanks to Fiona McMullan, Ciara Van Vogt and Barbara Emerson who supplied the food at the event for everyone to enjoy. It all went down a treat.Paula took over the reins of the pharmacy from her late father, Thomas McDaid, who was initially based in Kildare Street before moving to Castle Place three years later.This was when Paula joined her father in the pharmacy and she enjoyed  successful working years there before relocating once more to the Downpatrick Road ndash where it has cemented its place as a cornerstone of the village.Paula has poignantly decided that her last day behind the counter will be tomorrow mdash the same date as her fatherrsquos birthday, in what she describes as ldquoclosing off a circle.She said: ldquoThe Downpatrick Road premises will turn  years old on the date I retire. We opened it on my fatherrsquos nd birthday and I will say my goodbyes on what would have been his th birthday.ldquoI didnrsquot initially plan for that, but when I realised I could say a farewell on such a signicant date I thought it was fitting.Local people have also been reassured that the same members of staff will continue working in the establishment under the new owners, McKeevers Chemists.ldquoI would like to thank my staff for their loyalty, dedication and hard work, particularly through this particularly challenging time of Covid-. I couldnrsquot have done it without them, said Paula.ldquoAll the staff are still there and they will not be changing. Some of the members have been there as long as  years, theyrsquore like family to me.ldquoWersquove all grown up around the shop and itrsquos something I will miss but it means I can do things I have given a back seat to due to running a business.A long standing member of Ardglass Golf Club, she revealed how she missed being able to do the things she used to do freely before she took over the business.ldquoItrsquos a bitter-sweet feeling, and something which I am very emotional over. On the one hand I know I will miss the pharmacy dearly, but on the other hand I will get to enjoy my golf again and have time to myself, she said.A former competitor in the New York Marathon, she says she is looking forward to ldquoexciting new challenges.She added: ldquoWhen we are free to travel again I want to be able to grab those types of dferent opportunities with both hands..prettyPhoto

title: Birthday girl Brittany steers Irish girls to victory over Italy
story: KILLINCHYrsquoS Brittany Hogan had a rd birthday to remember as she helped Ireland to victory over Italy in the Womenrsquos Rugby World Cup.Brittany featured as a second half substitute as Ireland kept their qualying hopes alive with a vital - win over the hosts in Parma.Ireland had endured a nightmare start to their campaign after losing against underdogs Spain in what was a lacklustre performance from the girls in green.This loss meant they had to defeat the in-form Italians who recently enjoyed a scalp of their own, defeating Scotland by a score of -.However, tries from wingers Beibhinn Parsons and Amee-Leigh Murphy Crowe were enough to guide Ireland to a crucial win, which moves them into second place in the table.The group couldnrsquot be closer with all four teams on five points, with points scored making the dference.This Saturday the all-important final round of qualiers will commence, starting with Italy against Spain before Brittany and her Ireland teammates face off against Scotland at pm..prettyPhoto

title: Championship draws decided
story: FOLLOWING a pulsating opening round of action in this yearrsquos Down football championships, the draw has now been made for this weekrsquos fixtures.Reigning senior champions Kilcoo got revenge for their recent league upset by overcoming a halftime deficit to defeat Mayobridge in Newry at the weekend. The Magpies now square off against Clonduff in Paacuteirc Esler this Sunday at pm.Last yearrsquos runners-up, Carryduff, lost out to Downpatrick in what was a highly entertaining game on Saturday.Downpatrick progress to face Longstone this Saturday at pm, while Carryduff hope to shine under the Friday night lights in Liatroim against Senior Championship newcomers Saul.It was not the fairytale Saul were hoping for after they suffered a heavy defeat at the hands of the seasoned Burren.They now face an uphill battle and are surely considered underdogs against Carryduff in a match that throws in at .pm.Elsewhere, Loughinisland dramatically let a near-certain victory escape their grasp as they conceded two goals in as many minutes in the final quarter to fall short against Ballyholland.Jody Gormleyrsquos men will have to take the long routethey wish to achieve championship glory as they meet Mayobridge in Castlewellan this Saturday at pm.Bredagh overcame Castlewellan by a margin of three points in their opening fixture, with the Belfast side now set to meet Ballyholland in Newcastle this Sunday at pm.Castlewellan will face Rostrevor who lost their first round tie to Clonduff. That clash is scheduled for Ballymartin on Saturday at .pm.The last of the Senior Championship clashes is in Newry on Sunday at .pm when Bryansford, beaten by Glenn on Monday night, take on Warrenpoint, who were beaten by Longstone.The pick of the Intermediate Championship second round clashes is the tie between Darragh Cross and Liatroim, who overcame Saval and St Johnrsquos respectively in their openers. This one is scheduled for Sunday afternoon at pm.Saval face Dromara this Saturday at pm. Dromara lost out by just two points to Clann na Banna, despite leading at times throughout the match.St Johnrsquos also have a chance at redemption when they face Newry Shamrocks in Kilcoo on Monday at pm.Tullylish overturned a nine point deficit to defeat Division  winners Bright, who will now face St Paulrsquos in Drumaness on Saturday at pm.In the Junior Championship, Drumaness progressed to the quarter-finals with a comfortable victory over St Michaelrsquos.They are joined by Aughlisnafin, who managed to overcome a game Teconnaught side despite numerous players withdrawing due to isolation.Teconnaught now face Kilclief, who received a bye in their opener, this Saturday at pm in the qualying round.Dundrum managed to progress to the next round thanks to a win over Ardglass, who will now face Aghaderg at St Johnrsquos this Sunday at pm.Drumaness, Aughlisnafin and Dundrum will all have to wait until the qualying fixtures have been fulfilled before their quarter-final opponents are known..prettyPhoto

title: Consultation to help boost Downpatrick
story: THE business community in Downpatrick is to be consulted about what measures could be taken to support its continued regeneration and development at a time when there are  empty shop units across the town.Local council officials are behind the initiative after Newry, Mourne and Down Council recently debated potentially appointing a new town centre manager.While no final decision has been taken on appointing someone, the local authority wants to gauge the view of businesses on what they view as the priority moving forward post-Covid.The global pandemic hit a number of local businesses hard and while there are some politicians in favour of appointing a town centre manager to work in Downpatrick, others believe that the county town should not be given preferential treatment.Plans to speak with traders comes on the back of a recent proposal by Cllr Gareth Sharvin when the town centre manager issue was discussed at a meeting of the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee.Cllr Sharvin expressed concern about the number of empty business premises which includes three former banks which have been lying vacant for a number of years.The Downpatrick councillor said there are eight empty units at the Grove shopping centre in Market Street, three in Market Lane, alongside many others dotted around the town.ldquoLocal councillors recently met with Economic, Regeneration and Tourism officers to discuss theway forward in identying the best mechanism to support and move Downpatrick forward, revealed Cllr Sharvin.ldquoMy SDLP colleagues and I sees the revitalisation of Downpatrick as offering a unique opportunity to ensure that the town is ready to meet the opportunities of a post-Covid society. One of the most effective ways of identying how we meet these needs is consulting with our existing business stakeholders who have invested into our town and community.Cllr Sharvin said the proposed consultation will focus on the business communityrsquos view on what is positive about the work the local authority currently does.ldquoIt will also seek to find out what the organisation does not do so well, what businesses want to see in terms of support and what steps can be taken to attract additional investment, he continued.ldquoGiven Downpatrickrsquos rich and vibrant history, we have visitors coming from all over the world to visit St Patrickrsquos final resting place and complementing this is a fantastic array of attractions such as Inch Abbey, the St Patrick Centre, Downpatrick and Co Down Railway, Ballydugan medieval site, Struell Wells and Saul Church.ldquoHowever, the last thing I want is for those who visit the town and experience all this to then move on to Newry or Belfast.Cllr Sharvin said it is important that there are facilities for visitors to stay to have a meal and even remain in the town overnight.ldquoThis is something that I and my colleagues would like to see delivered which would have a positive,ripple effect on delivering a nightle that we can be proud of, he remarked.He said he believes that a town centre manager or a chamber of commerce could be the right mechanism to bring the town together and play a proactive role in attracting investment and new business to the area.He added: ldquoWe have to get the right blend of making Downpatrick attractive not only to tourists but, just as importantly, to residents who live and work in the area.ldquoI would urge all businesses to engage in the council survey and highlight what they would like to see in the Downpatrick area. It also important that they spell out how the local authority can support them to grow and make Downpatrick a top location for people to visit, stay and spend..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C September 26%2C 2001
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash Plans to develop a new cinema at Dunleath Park in Downpatrick have this week been abandoned by Down Council.The local authority has admitted the ambitious proposal earmarked for land adjacent to the Down Leisure Centre has fallen victim to legal and financial problems.However, councillors hope the complex can be developed at an alternative site where in the town centre and be up and running within the next few years.News of the shock decision to abort the Dunleath Park scheme was confirmed at a meeting in the town on Monday night when it was revealed that for legal and financial reasons, developing the facility at this location was simply not a viable option.If the council forged ahead with the plan for Dunleath Park, it would have to pay compensation to Dunleath Estates, based on the current commercial value of the land required to house the new cinema and associated parking.Alternatively,the existing lease is amended to allow the construction of the cinema, around one third of the income would have to be paid to Dunleath Estates with the remainder of the cash used specically for the playing fields, in keeping with stipulations laid down by the Charities Board when the lease was first drawn up.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A popular Ballynahinch newsagent has this week been forced out of business by burglars who ransacked his store.On Monday the shutters were pulled down on Ricersquos newsagents at High Street and are unlikely to be opened again by the current owner, Mr Eamonn Rice, who said the attack, the third in three years, has left him ldquomentally and physically wrecked.Thieves smashed their way into the store some time between Sunday night and the early hours of Monday morning and after stealing a large amount of property they completely destroyed anything in sight with crow bars and sledge hammers.Police believe the attack was carried out by professionals who are more than likely from outside the area, probably Belfast, and would have needed ready transport to escape with the goods.Yesterday Mr Rice as adamant that he did not want to have anything more to do with the shop saying that he could not go on working there after the heartless attack.KILLYLEAGH mdash A Killyleagh pensioner, who has been stripped of his -minute-a-day home help, has accused health officials of abandoning him.Seventy eight year-old John Heaney, who can only walk with the aid of walking sticks, says he is ldquogutted his home help service has been axed and claims the decision came out of the blue.Mr Heaney, from Grove Park, said the first he knew about the decision to remove his daily home help cam when the woman who has been attending him for the past number of years informed him two weeks ago she would not be back.He said he now has no idea what the future hold and fears what may happen when winter sets in and he has no help to light his fire in the morning.Local community worker Billy Walker, who is fighting the decision to remove Mr Heaneyrsquos home help assistance, said the pensioner cannot believe he has been singled out for such unfair treatment.The community worker said he understand the Down Lisburn Trust is strapped for cash to provide a number of community care services, including those aimed at specically helping elderly people.STRANGFORD mdash Pensioners have finally been granted free travel across Strangford Lough following a drawn out campaign by local politicians.Regional Development Minister Gregory Campbell announced the decision to include the Strangford to Portaferry crossing in the free travel for the elderly scheme during a meeting with Strangford MP Iris Robinson.Down councillor Peter Craig and Strangford MLA Kieran McCarthy have been at the forefront of the free travel for pensioners campaign.Describing the ferry crossing as a ldquovital service, Mr Campbell said he ldquofirmly believed free fares should be offered to senior citizens, in keeping with the Department for Regional Developmentrsquos policy to target concessions at users of public transport.The travel scheme will only be available to passengers over  years-old who are travelling by foot and will not be put into effect until January.The Ministerrsquos announcement comes at the same time as confirmation that the pound.m ferry, the MV Portaferry II, will be delivered towards the end of September.KILLOUGH mdash Residents in Killough have this week called for action to stop sand and shingle being removed from the villagersquos beach.They have appealed to local councillors for help in their battle to preserve the beauty of the foreshore which they fear is being irreparably damaged.Residents say diggers are being used to excavate large quantities of sand and shingle close to Fishermanrsquos Row and have already raised the issue with the Killough Community Association.Councillor Eamonn McConvey says he is concerned at what is happening and has asked Down Council to determinelegislation exists which prohibits sand and shingle being taken from the beach.NEWCASTLE mdash A telecommunications company which sparked controversy in Newcastle in recent weeks has taken steps towards healing damaged relations with local people.BT Cellnet representatives last week dismantled a mast at the Castlewellan Road in the town in an effort to appease the action group, Residents Against Masts , which was established to fight against the structure.The pressure group was formed last Monday night, just hours before the mast was erected against the wishes of local people who believe that it may put the health of children at risk.Following repeated calls by residents, BT Cellnet officials removed the -metre lamp post just two days later.The removal of the equipment has been hailed as a breakthrough by members of the RAM who have vowed to continue to fight against similar proposals in the town.A BT Cellnet spokesman this week confirmed that the mast had been taken down as a ldquogesture, but added that this was a ldquotemporary move.CASTLEWELLAN mdash Work to provide a new storm drain at a housing estate on the outskirts of Castlewellan is due to to start shortly.South Down MP Eddie McGrady has been lobbying the Housing Executive to ensure the drain is provided at the JFK estate in Burrendbridge as soon as possible.The MP said money for the scheme has been earmarked and revealed the drain will be provided at an alley-way at the rear of a number of houses.Mr McGrady said the drain is being installed in response to residentsrsquo complaints about flooding at their homes during exceptionally wet weather.ldquoThe contractor was due to start work last week and the scheme should take around one month to complete, he explained.ARDGLASS ndash Vandals who targeted a toilet block in Ardglass last week are doing nothing to help the image of the village.Councillor Dermot Curran said the people behind Sunday nightrsquos attack at the Quay have no understanding about the consequences their actions could have.The toilet block was badly damaged during the attack and an attempt was also made to set fire to the building which houses the only public toilet facility in the village.Describing the actions of the vandals as ldquodisgraceful and despicable, Mr Curran revealed the toilets will be closed for at least a week.He said at a time when a number of groups are aiming to raise the profile of Ardglass, along comes a group which targets a toilet block.ldquoThese people have no understanding about the impact their attacks will have on the village and the people who live in Ardglass, he declared.Mr Curran said in addition to the weekend vandal attack, litter was also thrown over the playing fields in the village..prettyPhoto

title: Helping residents living in social isolation
story: LAST month I launched my mental health initiative for Newry, Mourne and Down Council around the impact of rural isolation.Across the district, the geographical range that our constituents span is monumental in comparison to our population. That being said, it is no wonder that our rural communities may feel isolated from our bigger towns and cities, where investment and opportunities are more obvious.Rural isolation is closer to all of us than we realise exploring this topic brought to light my own childhood memories of growing up in the countryside.While I loved my upbringing, I hadnrsquot considered how it was impacted by the fact that I grew up in a rural area. It was through exploring the topic of rural isolation that I realised the social effects it can have on our youth.My own children are growing up in the countryside as well and I can now see how this may impact them socially they are not playing with friends in the evenings like many would in housing developments and built up areas.They are playing with each other in their own garden, similar to my own experience. While I donrsquot think this is a negative thing for my children, due to the volume of social groups and clubs that they participate in, I am now consciously taking opportunities to expose them to a wider iety of social situations, so they do not feel the potential effects of rural isolation.It is clear to see the effects of rural isolation when just recently at a meeting with Translink, the cutting of rural bus routes and services was brought to light. This is another slap in the face to those living in rural areas without access to their own vehicle, especially when considering the climate crisis.I and my fellow councillors and party colleagues are encouraging constituents to use active travel and public transport.Meanwhile, those exact services are being cut removing the option for active travel. This is not good enough.I have conducted a range of investigative meetings to see how groups and organisations within South Down in particular are taking action to prevent rural isolation.I recently met with Nicholas McCrickard, manager of Co Down Rural Community Network, an organisation crucial in combatting rural isolation in South Down as itrsquos an umbrella body set up and managed by community groups in the area for more than  years.The aim of the organisation is to create an inclusive future where all citizens actively participate in local le which stimulates a vibrant society.Nicholas and his team, with the support of community groups, ensure regular outreach to all of the citizens in the area so that they can enhance their own lives through participation with ious organisations. This stimulation is a sure-fire way to combat rural isolation, but the resources need to be available to ensure no one is left behind.I recently visited the offices of Good Morning Down in Downpatrick mdash another vital service many in our community rely on. It is an organisation which regularly makes telephone calls to those facing isolation for a iety of reasons. These calls are a method of friendship building between volunteers and residents of a wide iety of ages.The youngest volunteer in Good Morning Down is in their late s, while the eldest is in their late s. Nearly  years worth of knowledge and experience will be exchanged through these conversations and I walked away from this meeting, feeling truly touched by the dedication of the staff and volunteers.In addition, having met with Womenrsquos Aid in recent days, fresh in my mind are the stories of the impact that living in a rural setting has on many women who are isolated from much of society.Not having that friendly neighbour close by can impact the severity of abusive relationships. Thankfully, we have organisations such as Womenrsquos Aid who recognise this and work every day with women in these situations, but funding, resourcing and legislation is always an issue.These are only a few of the fantastic initiatives that offer support to those in rural communities, however, there are many who are unaware of their operation.I would like to raise awareness of the services available to our rural constituents, to promote inclusivity and encourage a positive approach to mental health and wellbeing. It is extremely important to raise awareness and encourage our rural communities to stop and think about their mental health and to consider how rural isolation may affect them.I would encourage our rural communities to take time out to improve their mental health, normalise discussion around issues of isolation and avail of local mental health services.It is time that Newry, Mourne and Down Council took responsibility and recognise the vital work local groups within our community do for the residents of our district and remember that ratepayers donrsquot just live in our major towns like Downpatrick, but also in rural areas such as the wider Lecale countryside.There needs to be a serious refocusing on service provision in rural areas and a renewed approach to capital investment. We need to stand up for the safety of our rural communities, and protect them from the effects of isolation. Rural communities cannot continue to be left behind..prettyPhoto

title: It’s goals that count for RGU
story: DOWNPATRICK kick-started their Senior Championship campaign with an impressive win over last yearrsquos runners-up Carryduff on a sun-drenched Saturday evening.Despite being considered slight underdogs before the contest, the green and white outfit proved they were anything but as they found the back of the net three times in the opening half.Goals from Oran Cunninghamand captain Conor McGrady put the Hoops too far in front at the interval, with the Carryduff men left frustrated at their missed chances.There was a notable turnout at the Darragh Cross venue, with waves of supporters from both sides allowing their voices to be heard throughout the duration of the match.Despite Carryduff winning the throw-in, it was Downpatrick who opened the scoring through a Jarlath Brannigan free after three minutes had been played.Brannigan doubled his tally just two minutes later in what was a determined start from the Hoops.However, this would be no stroll in the park as Josh Connery dummied his marker to send Carryduffrsquos first effort over the bar after some silky work from team-mate Owen McCabe.Downpatrick goalkeeper and joint captain James Deeny displayed pin-point accuracy with his kick-outs countless times throughout the match but perhaps needed the opening minutes to settle any nerves.A wayward punt upfield was gobbled up by Carryduffrsquos Pearse McCabe who relayed the ball quickly to Cian Clinton to level the scores.Caolan Mooney made his presence known with his usual rapid pace and precision. The former Rostrevor and current county player drew a foul before Conor McCarron calmly converted to put Downpatrick back in front.It was Carryduffrsquos turn to showcase their county talent as Daniel Guinness again levelled the tie with an emphatic point before captain Joe McFlynn swung the match back in their favour.However, with a minute to go to the first water-break Downpatrick got the reward for their relentless work in the middle of the park.McGrady and Mooney swarmed the Carryduff midfield with a barrage of tackles before some quick passing allowed the ball to enter into the hands of Downpatrickrsquos young forward Oran Cunningham.The Downpatrick number  made no mistake in blasting his effort past opposing lsquokeeper Mark Hynes to give his side a two-point lead.This advantage didnrsquot last until the quarter as Carryduff replied with two well-taken scores to bring the contest even.A few wides from both sides were observed after the water-break before Conor Doherty curled his left-footed free in-between the posts for Downpatrick.With  minutes played on the clock it was Cunningham again who would prove the major dference after his long-ranged effort looped over the head of Hynes and into the back of the net to double his tally.Hynes could be excused for this as Cunninghamrsquos effort struck most around the pitch as a cross rather than an attempt at goal.Nevertheless, Carryduff kept plugging away and answered with a James Guinness point.Conor McGrady saw his effort at goal crowded out by the determined opposing defenders before Gerdie Collins saw his effort drt over the bar to restore Downpatrickrsquos four-point lead.Mooney pointed again for the Hoops before McGrady added his sidersquos third goal of the half after the green and white forward line took advantage of a defensive mix-up.Daniel Guinness tried to rally his team as best as he could, soloing past three RGU shirts before registering the final point of the half. Half-time: Downpatrick - Carryduff -.Whatever the management team of Paddy Doherty, Shane OrsquoNeill and DJ Morgan told their Carryduff side during the interval must have struck a chord as they started the second half with clear intent.Despite a James Guinness wide, points from McCabe and McFlynn chipped away at the deficit for the purple, gold and black side.Cunningham was unlucky not to hit a hat-trick of goals after his lobbed effort was fantastically cleared of the line by Daniel Coogan.RGU followed this up with two efforts which both veered wide, before McFlynn again pointed for Carryduff leaving the score - to - in favour of the Downpatrick side at the second water-break.It was clear that legs were beginning to tire in the final quarter after a gruelling physical showing from both teams meant more and more chances went begging.Downpatrick finally registered their first point of the second half through another Doherty free.Carryduff refused to go quietly and were given added encouragement when RGUrsquos Tim Prenter was shown a black card with five minutes remaining.However, the frustration continued for both Carryduff and James Guinness as his effort veered wide of the target again.Deeny was rewarded for keeping his concentration after making an impressive save with his feet to deny Carryduff a certain goal in the dying moments of the game, although he could do nothing about the converted free a minute later.Mooney fisted over the bar in the next run of play for Downpatrick before Carryduff substitute Joe Tunney completed the scoring in the last passage of play.After the match, Downpatrick manager Aidan Robinson reflected on his sidersquos winning performance.ldquoIn the first half we worked incredibly hard, we turned the ball over a lot at the halfway line which we got a lot of scores from and we managed to get the goals, he said.ldquoWe built a good  for ourselves and spoke at half-time about kicking on from that, but we didnrsquot really manage to.ldquoI think in the third quarter of the game we were pretty flat and Carryduff got back into the tie, but we got over the line and we will learn from that.He added: ldquoIrsquom very happy with the result and very happy to be in the next round.Downpatrick: J Deeny, E Rooney, A Doherty, R Murphy, T Smyth, J Bell, C Doherty, D Turley, C McCarron, T Prenter, G Collins, C McGrady, J Brannigan, P Turley, C Mooney.Subs: A Og Robinson, M Fitzpatrick, O Cunningham, S Bell, T Loudon, T McNeill, N Cunningham, D Brannf, T Savage, C Boyd, R Og Quinn, C Farrell, R Quinn.Carryduff: M Hynes, D Coogan, C Cassidy, C McCullagh, L Toal, J Connery, D Guinness, B Cox, P McCabe, O McCabe, J McFlynn, C Clinton, S McGonigle, R Beatty, J Guinness.Subs: T Connery, M McGrath, P McConnell, C Sherry, R Reilly, C Cunningham, R Boyle, J Tunney, M Lawson, C Rooney, J Henry, D Connelly, D Connor.Downpatrick -Carryduff -MORGAN FUELS SFC ST ROUND.prettyPhoto

title: Local actors Shine in short movie filmed around East Down
story: LOCAL actors have been lighting up the big screen in a short film that has recently scooped a notable cinematic award.lsquoShinersquo wrapped up filming last November after cast and crew spent months shooting in a host of local areas such as Bright and Kilmore, and now it has been crowned the lsquoBest Online Short Filmrsquo at the Dublin Underground Film Cinema Festival.The movie has also been listed as a semi-finalist at this monthrsquos Cannes World Film Festival, whereits success is to continue, will make it through to next yearrsquos final.The dramatic tale tells the story of Nick, a young man who lacks confidence in expressing his dreams to his traditional family, and who is tasked with balancing his work le with helping his father on their family farm.Part-time director, writer and actor Declan Curran from Attical, drafted in favours from family members and friends to help bring his debut production to le.The film was an unfunded, therefore it was created with a very limited number of cast and crew.Declandescribed filming in his unclersquos ldquohundreds of years-old cottage in Bright as an ldquoouter body experience, but it was just one of the many things included in the -minute long flick which was close to his heart.ldquoI couldnrsquot be more grateful to my family and friends for their commitment, time and effort of the course of making this film, he said.ldquoI would never have been able to make this dream of mine a reality without them, therersquos loads of personal touches included in the film.The upcoming talent had the help of Bright natives Jimmy and John McIlmailwho star in roles as lsquoFather Hughesrsquo and lsquoJohnnyrsquo.Speaking about Jimmyrsquos role as the priest, Declan says despite his great uncle being completely new to the acting world, ldquothere was no better man for the job.ldquoI actually had Jimmy in mind when I wrote the character of Father Hughes, so it just made sense to me that he was the one to portray him, he said.ldquoThe priest appears in a bus with myself [Nick] during the film, and I actually was wearing my late granddads cap in that scene while my mother Dolores made the priest collar Jimmy was wearing, so it was very family orientated.ldquoDue to Covid- we faced a dficult year in filming, so we had to try find ways around things for shooting. For that particular scene, we approached Kilmore Coach Hire who drove us around the village until we got what we needed.The cast and crew also filmed inside Bright Parish Church before they set off to allow a christening to take place.ldquoWe were lucky the farmer who owned the surrounding fields was so generous in allowing us to film, as well as the church minister, said Declan.ldquoIt was kindness such as this from the locals which allowed us to make this happen.The McIlmail duo were not the only local faces who appeared in the award winning short, as Newcastlersquos Sandra Brown portrays lsquoMaggiersquo and Crossgarrsquos Chris Heath takes up the role of lsquoEamonrsquo.Notably, not all of these cast members have actually met each other in person. Due to the restrictions in place, actors only metthey were in the same scene.Declanrsquos cousin, Aroacuten Holden from Downpatrick, was the editor for the film who helped piece each scene together. Aroacuten also introduced Declan to a number of others who assisted in creating the short, and therefore was referred to as ldquoan invaluable help by the young director.The short continues to enter numerous film festivals in the hopes of adding more honours, including ceremonies in England, Scotland and the USA.Meanwhile, Declan is currently directing a new featurefilm based in Belfast named lsquoThe Trick Roomrsquo, which entails the story of a cross-community cricket team.To keep up to date with the latest news surrounding Shine, visit @shine_shortfilm on Instagram or check out https:www.imdb title tt ..prettyPhoto

title: Locals among the prizes at Downpatrick meeting
story: IT was a good day for local owners and trainers at Fridayrsquos penultimate meeting of the year at Downpatrick.They were successful in three of the seven races on the card, that featured four over hurdles, two chases and a bumper. The first and longest priced winner of the three came in the second race, the Franco Hughes Bookmaker Handicap Hurdle.So Near So Farhh swept into the lead after the last flight, going clear up the climb to the post to win from Dazzling Darren, a winner of his two previous races. Back in third came Amlad.For winning rider James OrsquoSullivan it was his first success for Raffrey trainer Colin McBratney, who was recording his first track success in a year.The winner is owned by Comber contractor James Murdoch and it was good to see these colours in the winnerrsquos enclosure as they were used to for many years by his late father, better known as The Rancher and a real gentleman. SP:  ,  , fav  .The second locally owned, trained and bred winner came in the Northern Ireland On Course Bookmakers Handicap Hurdle when recent course winner Willyouwalkwithme, with Wexford jockey Shane Fitzgerald in the saddle, made every post a winning one to beat Fassbender, ridden by Denis OrsquoRegan and regular runner at Downpatrick Alexharwill, ridden by local jockey Ryan Treacy.The winner is one of only three horses owned and trained at Ballyclare by former top stock car driver Harry Smyth, who at the age of  is Northern Irelandrsquos senior trainer,Itrsquos hard to believe that Harry, who has a good strike rate and has reasonably training fees is not supported by owners at Sligo. On Wednesday he saddled Zagnig to finish second under Armagh jockey Shane OrsquoGallaghan.As Harry says about his horses: ldquoI be good to them, so I expect them to be good to me.Willyouwalkwithme was bred at Chapeltown, near Ardglass, by Kieran Magee. SP  ,  ,  .We then had to wait until the sixth race, a handicap chase over two miles and seven furlongs, for the third local success and front running again paid off as Bryan Cooper had Archies Charm up with the pace all the way to win in good style over Pat Coyne and Chesterville.The winner was providing popular Dromara owner David Aiken, owner of F S Herron, with a welcome change of luck. It was also a welcome success for Ballynoe trainer Brian Hamilton, who has a large string in training at present. SP:  ,  ,   fav.Also over fences was the Beginners Chase and as The Abbey held a clear lead over the last fence it looked like Davy Russell was going to record a winningto action, but on the climb to the winning post he had to give best to Hurricane Georgie, ridden by Jordan Gainford, with Seanbhothar back in third.Both first and second are trained by Gordon Elliott, who has not lost any time getting back into the winnerrsquos enclosure following his six month suspension.So long champion trainer at the local track, he then went on to record a double with   fav Top Bandit, with Jamie Codd on board, a very easy winner of the bumper. Second was Mary Meehan with Woodstream Lad third.Meath trainer John McConnell rates Downpatrick as the best racecourse in Ireland and no wonder as he has had a great year at the venuel When his charge, Ally Cay, won the Bar One Racing Rated Novice Hurdle in style, it was his fth success in the last three meetings at the track.Ridden by Jack Gilligan, who was having his initial ride for the trainer, the   winner proved too good for the   fav Mars Harperand Belles Benefit.The first race of the day was the Bill McIlroy Bookmaker Maiden Hurdle and here Serenity Groversquos task was made easier when Wild Shot sprawled at the last flight on landing, but stayed on well to finish third behind The Greek and Davy Russell, ridden by Darragh OrsquoKeefe, the current leader in the jockeyrsquos championship. The winner is trained in Waterford by Henry De Bromhead.The final meeting of the year is on Friday, October .Local racing has lost another great supporter with the passing of Corinne McAllister, well known as the owner of the Morning Star Bar in Belfast along with her late husband Seamus, who had many horses in training over the years. When Seamus passed away Corinne had horses in her own name or as part of a syndicate. She was a well known figure at local point-to-points in her wax coat and wellies, often accompanied by her dogs and daughter Peita.Another great loss to local racing. She will be greatly missed..prettyPhoto

title: Musical garden party raises hundreds for local charities
story: THE recent musical charity garden party organised by the Rowallane and Slieve Croob Community Twinning Group raised pound, for five local charities.Hosted by Mr Hugh and Mrs Violet Hawthorne at their Diary Lake House at Old Belfast Road in Ballynahinch, the event was a great success and was favoured with fine weather.Over  people attended the garden party which is the th to be hosted by the local couple, with guests enjoying afternoon tea and treated to a number of superb performances.Musical performers included the Alastair Scott Ceilidh Band, Sam Gill and his sons Jack and Charlie from Hollymount Pipe Band with music and melodies provided by Mr Gerry Walsh, Mr Brian and Mrs Monica Megoran and the Ballygowan Community Choir.Dotted around the garden, guests were able to engage with local artists who presented their creative displays which included painting, wood turning, gt cards and flower arranging.In addition, children enjoyed creative story telling by Pamela Dickson and Antoinette Campbell from Ballynahinch library.The raffle and auction of many ied and valuable prizes was a great success and contributed to the enjoyment of the day.The Twinning Group would like to thank Montalto Estate, the Primrose Bar and Restaurant, Drumlins Restaurant, Temple Golf Club, Thomas Kellyrsquos, Stewart and Gibson, McCoubreyrsquos Electrical, Kitchen Master, Joseph Morrowrsquos gents outfitters, Z-Cut, Watsonrsquos Flower Shop, Bennettyrsquos Fish and Chips, Cuts both Ways, EuroSpar Drumaness, AJC Group Downpatrick, Gordonrsquos Chemist, Vivo Extra, Carlisle Fresh Foods, Eamonn McAuley Interior Design, the Autogrid and Magowan Fashions for their generous donations, prizes and vouchers.ldquoWe are pleased that we raised a total of pound, at the garden party, said Twinning Group chairwoman Karen Patterson.ldquoThe money raised will be donated to our five chosen charities this year which are Ballynahinch Counselling Services, Northern Ireland Chest Heart and Stroke, Northern Ireland Alzheimerrsquos Society, Air Ambulance NI and Diabetes NI.Ms Patterson said the cheques will be presented to the ious organisations over the coming weeks.ldquoWe would like to thank everyone who in any way supported the recent event, she added..prettyPhoto

title: Portaferry singer Jonny goes to No1 Down Under
story: A DEBUT album from a Portaferry musician has gone straight to the top Down Under.Jonny Reidrsquos album, Another Le, came out two weeks ago and went in at number one in Australian country charts and number three on the iTunes album charts.A former luthier at Lowden Guitars in Downpatrick for six years, Jonny released the title track from his album on July .He has been living and working as a full-time musician in Perth for the past nine years.While he has not been home since before the global pandemic started, the  year-old has had help from his home town with his new album.ldquoI recorded my album here in Australia at Scudley Records in Perth and also with the help from home via Portaferry multi-instrumentalist and country star Stephen Smyth in his Loughside Recording Studios who we sent tracks back and forward to so he could add his magic, said Jonny.ldquoTherersquos songs on the new album about travel and experiences from Ireland to Australia. Songs about love and wicked exes. Therersquos even a song about killing a barman.He has opened for international acts such as Richie Sambora from Bon Jovi and country music legend, Nancy Grfiths Reid.Jonny left Co Down in  for a year-long working holiday where he would play gigs as he travelled the country And he has now set down roots by getting engaged to a woman from Co Waterford that he met in Australia.However, home is still very close to his heart as his parents moved from Portaferry to Cloughey a few years ago.Jonny intends tohome to visit family and perform his album as soon as itrsquos possible.To follow Jonnyrsquos music, visit Facebook jonnyreidmusic or on my website www.jonnyreidmusic.prettyPhoto

title: Pro IRA graffiti blasted
story: A LOCAL politician has branded those responsible for daubing pro-IRA graffiti on a bridge bear Dundrum as ldquoidiotic.Slieve Croob councillor Alan Lewis believes the culprits have demonstrated what he described as an ldquounfortunate increase in bigotry and said it is beyond him why ldquosomeone would be so stupid.The graffiti was daubed on a section of the Moneycarragh bridge mdash also known locally as Bennettrsquos bridge mdash with Cllr Lewis saying what happened was ldquoidiotic and void of reason and that defacing the historic bridge demonstrated ldquoovert sectarianism.Cllr Lewis said while police may not be able to identy those responsible, he was told that neighbours can.ldquoThe aspiring republican artists should be thoroughly embarrassed by their actions and I only hope that their parents are reading this article, he declared.ldquoThis part of rural South Down suffered heavily as a direct result of IRA terrorism. Those with a spray can in one hand and a smartphone which accesses the internet in the other may have learnt or been fed a misguided, romanticised version of the troubles.ldquoI can assure them that their neighbours, the community which lives around them and which suffered day and daily do not need reminded of lsquoProvo brutalityrsquo nor do they expect to see such obvious triumphalism.Cllr Lewis believes that the paint daubed on the bridge is strikingly similar to that which was used to paint over a dual language sign at the Wateresk Road outside Dundrum.ldquoThis suggests to me that those involved may have been trying to create the illusion that the Irish language sign was attacked by unionist neighbours to create tension and sow ision, he declared. ldquoThis type of behaviour is not welcome, it is not wanted and needs to stop.Cllr Lewis said he was unable to remove the graffiti from the bridge and has asked the Department for Infrastructure to do it..prettyPhoto

title: Saints are held in stalemate
story: SAINTFIELD were looking to build on last weekrsquos win and made the trip to Larne to play Wellington Rec, who, bizarrely, were only making their first home appearance in the league this season.The home pitch was in much better order than the Saintsrsquo last visit mdash albeit the grass was a bit on the long side mdash and it did take the visitors a while to adjust to playing on.The conditions, along with a sluggish start from Saintfield, meant a very even first halfrsquos only real highlight was a disputed offside call which denied Peter Boylan his second goal in as many games.In the second half, Saintfield showed more of their ability and created much better opportunities but like last weekrsquos performance they failed to convert some decent openings.A harsh sending off on the hour mark meant an adjustment to shape, which threatened to allow the home side to take control of the game.Their long throws were causing problems for the Saints defence and from this threat, Wellington created their best opening of the game forcing a good save from Harper followed by a goal line clearance from Simpson.Saintfield responded by gaining control in midfield and looked by far the more threatening side with Stonemans effort off the post the best of four or five good opportunities created without reward.In the end, the refereersquos whistle left the Saints with mixed emotions, pleased to come back from Larne with a point having played  minutes with ten men, yet disappointed that all three points should probably have been claimed.Wellington Rec FC Saintfield United AMATEUR LEAGUE DIV C.prettyPhoto

title: Shoppers urged to shop local and spend £100 voucher in high street
story: PEOPLE across the district are being urged to spend their new pound High Street pre-paid voucher cards to support local businesses.The appeal by Newry, Mourne and Down Council comes after applications for the poundm scheme opened on Monday, with the first cards due to be issued later this week.The Northern Ireland Executiversquos programme mdash which applies to everyone over  mdash aims to help those businesses in retail and hospitality hit by the pandemic and comes after the local council recently launched a lsquomake it localrsquo initiative to support local traders.Council chairwoman Cathy Mason said this campaign not only shines a light on the key sectors represented across the district, but highlights how businesses have worked hard to establish a safe shopping practice in light of Covid- regulations.ldquoIt has been a particularly dficult period for our local traders and the voucher scheme is a great initiative that has come at an ideal time as we approach the winter holiday season, she said.ldquoThe initiative will help boost our local businesses following thein footfall and reduced trade brought about by the pandemic.Cllr Mason said the clear message is that Newry, Mourne and Down is open for business.She added: ldquoOur local businesses are outstanding, erse and resilient. Now is the time to step up and support them by making it local. I would strongly encourage people from within the district to avail of the voucher and shop locally.Downpatrick businessman Darren Kearney, who is the owner of Oakley Fayre, said the business is pleased to be open to near full capacity again, which has only been made possible with the support of staff and loyal customers.ldquoThis has been a dficult time for many industries and the hospitality industry has been hit very hard, so we welcome any incentive or investment scheme that will help bring people onto their local high street, he said.Mr Kearney added: ldquoSupporting local gives back to the small, family-run businesses that are the foundation of the Northern Ireland economy.Stormont Economy Minister Gordon Lyons is encouraging local businesses to support the initiative.He said the ldquounprecedented scheme, which closes on November , is designed to boost businesses across the retail, hospitality and service sectors following the impact of the Covid- pandemic.He is urging all businesses to show their support to help maximise the benefits of the Spend Local cards and to use them wisely, supporting the local economy and communities as a ldquolittle spend can have a big effect.Retail NI chief executive Glyn Roberts said the scheme comes on the back of a very challenging period for retailers right across Northern Ireland.ldquoThe High Street Support Scheme is a welcome step in the long road to recovery for Northern Irelandrsquos retailers and I would encourage everyone in our industry to think hard about how they can encourage people to use their pound spend local card with their business, he said.ldquoIt should be remembered that p in every pound spent in an independent retailer is recycled around the local economy. If consumers make a special effort to spend their pound with local traders, then they will also be ensuring the money also goes towards invigorating the wider community.Hospitality Ulster chief executive Colin Neill said the impact of Covid- continues to present major challenges for the hospitality industry across Northern Ireland.ldquoThere is a great deal of uncertainty in the industry at the minute, he said.ldquoThe pandemic has had a devastating impact right across the sector. We welcome the introduction of the High Street scheme, which is a great opportunity for people to support jobs of friends and family who work in hospitality while enjoying some of the best food and drink in the world.Meanwhile, both the business community and the public are warned to be on their guard against scammers attempting to take advantage of the scheme. The Department of the Economy said it will not be asking for personal bank details at any point during the scheme..prettyPhoto

title: Structures needed around Strangford ferry service
story: POLITICIANS from adjoining local authority areas met last week to continue their work in addressing issues in relation to the Strangford ferry service.Newry, Mourne and Down councillor Cadogan Enright met with his Ards and North Down counterpart, Joe Boyle.They have been working in tandem for some time to address issues around the ferry service with some success already under their belt, particularly on the Portaferry side of the waterway.Cllr Enright said a lot of the issues they have concerns about are under the control of the Department of Infrastructure, not the local ferry staff who, he said, ldquodo a great job.He explained that over the past year the councillors succeeded in securing a new early morning sailing from Portaferry for commuters and students alike.ldquoPrior to Covid, it was common for capacity issues in the morning, forcing some people to drive around the peninsula or leave their cars in Strangford, Cllr Enright explained.ldquoCllr Boyle and I are campaigning to reduce congestion in Strangford by having the ferry car park in the village used as part of the ferry operation as is currently the case Portaferry. This would help ensure that the centre of Strangford does not become a car park which happens regularly.Cllr Enright thanked residents for their support on the traffic issue in Strangford and confirmed that the Stormont department has accepted the traffic tailbacks causes problems and that the issue needs to be addressed.He said officials have allocated a small budget to employ additional staff to ensure that the dedicated ferry queuing area is utilised at peak periods to reduce congestion in the centre of the village.Cllr Boyle agrees that a permanent solution is required to address the queuing issue in Strangford.He continued: ldquoWe must promote tourism to its fullest potential on both sides of Strangford Lough. That means that we need structures in place that maintain a steady flow of traffic through both Strangford and Portaferry.ldquoWe simply cannot continue with Strangford village regularly coming to a standstill, with residents being seriously affected, creating a negative rather than positive impact on local businesses and le in general due to ferry traffic.Cllr Boyle said Strangford and Portaferry had much to gain from tourism, provided there were proper structures in place to deal with vehicles wishing to board vessels on either side of the lough.He said he has discussed the problem with Cllr Enright and they believe there is a simple, cost-effective solution to addressing the problem.Cllr Boyle said it is important that visitors and tourists have a positive, not negative experience of both villages, confirming that both politicians plan to progress the issue with senior Department for Infrastructure officials.He said they also hope to contact with Stormont Infrastructure Minister Nichola Mallon..prettyPhoto

title: Wheelchair beach access plan
story: THE possibility of trialling floating wheelchairs at beaches across the district is being considered by Newry, Mourne and Down Council.The move comes after the local authority was asked to address the lack of access to beaches for those with mobility problems and officers asked to look at potential solutions.A number of politicians say they recognise the need to do more to ensure beaches can be accessed by a wide range of people by providing floating wheelchairs and special matting to allow them to travel over sand to make it to the water.The issue was discussed at last weekrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Active and Healthy Communities Committee with officers agreeing to bring back a report for discussion next month.Initially, officials will examine access to Newcastle beach before focusing on others across the district.Local councillors Patrick Brown and Alan Lewis are spearheading the drive to provide improved beach access, especially as there a number of local facilities which have been awarded prestigious blue flag status which recognises their quality.In a report presented to members of the council committee last week, officers said they were currently investigating several options and a further report will be tabled in October.She also issued a reminder of ongoing consultation on so-called changing places provision which is designed to meet the needs of people with a range of mobility issues.Cllr Harte said not everyone in a wheelchair was mobile and would need a hoist. Therefore there wouldnrsquot be much point providing floating wheelchairsthe council did not have the facilities for these people to get into or access these wheelchairs.Independent councillor Jarlath Tinnelly said that the beach access issue had been raised with him throughout the summer and he called for other beaches to be included in the pilot.He said his only concern with the motion would be thata pilot project was being proposed, the councilrsquos blue flag beaches at Tyrella and Cranfield should be considered.ldquoThe experience of wheelchair users to get on to the beach and enjoy that same thrill is a priority and we should be doing whatever we can to facilitate that, he said.ldquoThese floating wheelchairs can be taken into the water and allow people to enjoy the same experiences as everybody , things that are taken for granted.The motion to improve beach access was initially tabled in August and was inspired by the campaigning work of local activist, Naomi Herron, who approached all her local councillors askingsomething could be done to give her better access to the beach.At the time, Cllr Brown said he understood that while a small scale trial of the idea has operated in Cranfield in the past, it was important that this was expanded out into other parts of the district and that he could ldquothink of no better place than Newcastle given the large number of visitors it gets every year.He continued: ldquoAs a council, it is important that we ensure all facilities are open and accessible to all residents. It is right that we look at the issue of beach access, with a view to providing provisions for wheelchair-bound residents and visitors who wish to also enjoy our wonderful coastline.ldquo I donrsquot want this issue to go around in circles with reports, meetings and investigations. It is my hope that from this motion we see action, movement toward making the necessary access points needed to facilitate this initiative. Disabled beach access is a reality in other towns within these islands why not Newcastle.Cllr Lewis said work was needed to ensure the entire district is disabled access friendly, from changing to toilet facilities.He added: ldquoIncreased footfall to Newcastle during the good weather has brought many of these issues to the fore. As councillors, we must challenge ourselves to ensure that our district is accessible and open to all by facilitating the extra provisions needed..prettyPhoto

story: Northern Ireland Office did not follow own rules on ‘equality screening’ for Troubles legacy plans – new report   Dublin and Brussels ‘changing their tune’ on Northern Ireland Protocol: Sir Jeffrey DonaldsonNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionLord Dodds: The DUP has consistently opposed any border in the Irish SeaA letter from Lord Dodds of Duncairn OBE:By Nigel DoddsWednesday, th September , : pmUpdated Wednesday, th September , : pm  "       "  We opposed the Michel Barnier-Theresa May backstop which created a regulatory border when some unionists, and many in business and civic leadership, were enthusiastic for itThe attempts to revise history don’t end with republicanism’s attempts concerning the violence of the past. There are so-called unionists who instead of uniting with like-minded unionists to fight off the Northern Ireland Protocol, are instead desperate to score petty party political points, hiding behind pseudonyms to do so The record is clear. From the first mention of the Barnier backstop in February  to the calling of the general election in November  the DUP at Westminster consistently and sometimes alone led principled opposition to any notion of Northern Ireland being in a dferent single market or customs arrangement than the rest of the UK.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...We consistently opposed the Theresa May backstop which created a regulatory border when some unionists, and many in business and civic leadership, were enthusiastic for it. We voted it down three times in the House of Commons in the midst of intense pressure to come round and vote for it.We consistently opposed Boris Johnson’s Protocol. Indeed, days before he succeeded in getting the Lib Dems and SNP to vote for a general election, we had stopped the protocol being progressed by winning a vote against his timetable motion. We supported the creation of a veto for the Northern Ireland Assembly by requiring a cross community vote for the creation of any regulatory borders. That is not support for a regulatory border. That is a veto on a regulatory border. That would have put the matter in our own hands, not the hands of London, or Dublin, or Brussels. Our position would have ensured that Northern Ireland was in the same position as the rest of the UK as far as the single market was concerned. No amount of revisionism by republicanism, or some in unionism, will succeed in altering the facts.Lord Dodds of Duncairn OBE, Former DUP deputy leaderLetter: DUP support for a regulatory border in the Irish Sea in  was a catastrophic error——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communitySky has unveiled the first look image of star Samantha Morton in their original, Save The Cinema.The film is inspired by theextraordinary real-le events sparked by tenacious hairdresser Liz Evans .Save The Cinemaillustrates how the resolve of the people of Carmarthen, inspired by the magic of cinema, was able to bring Tinseltown to their doorstep.Inspired by the le of Liz Evans,as she attempts to #SaveTheCinema  stop the council from taking the heart of the community away.Will writing a letter to Hollywood save the day Save The Cinema, A #SkyOriginal film, available  January  # pic KbsYhTlBGLmdash Sky TVSeptember , Carmarthen in Wales is not exactly the first place to spring to mind when thinking of Hollywood blockbusters.But this changed in  when the town council made the unwelcome announcement that The Lyric Theatre ndash the townrsquos much-loved but financially stricken cinema ndash would be demolished so a shopping centre could be built in its place. #Itrsquos down to Liz Evans, hairdresser and linchpin to the local community, to stand up for the ailing cinema and stop the bulldozers.As she and her friends barricade themselves in the theatre, she reaches out to postman turned town councillor Richardfor help - and they come up with a grand plan.First look of #SavetheCinema starring Samantha Morton as Liz EvansThe story of how the Lyric theatre cinema in Carmarthen was savedWill never forget my time as a volunteer at the Lyric and when we had a Jurassic Park premiereIn cinemas  on Sky Cinemas from th January  pic qeTSZqoSBmdash Ioan DyerSeptember , To revitalise the cinema and stop the council taking the heart of the community away, a desperate Liz persuades Richard to write to Hollywood to ask for a helping hand. title: penarth district ramblers enjoy walk starting bonvilston
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityWhile not a great deal is known about the history of the village, there are signs of early occupation in the form of a Bronze Age flint tool and cooking mounds that have been discovered. The name of Bonvilston or Tresimwn dates back to the th century when the Norman lord Simon de Bonville was granted the manor by Robert Fitzhamon, Lord of Glamorgan and he constructed a ringwork castle as added protection for the castles at Dinas Powys and Sully.There are also references to monks being at Bonvilston and in a papal bull which is a public decree or charter issued by the Pope, a grange was mentioned in .When the parish became part of the Cottrell Estate, the last resident of Cottrell House was Mackintosh of Mackintosh from Moy in Scotland who was married to Lady Maud Cavendish. In  she donated the reading room for the male population of the village to learn to read, but it wasnrsquot until  that women were allowed in.At the end of the th century the Bassett family owned the estate and the family lived at Bonvilston House for more than  years. The house passed on through more famous names like Tudor Crawshay, the grandson of the well-known Ironmaster William Crawshay and then into the Brains brewery family. Although the house was demolished in  the lodge still remains.Gathering at Maes-y-Ffynon, which was built between  and  the group followed the bridleway at the far end of the road and walking between green hedges arrived at the busy lane which leads to Pendoylan. Crossing the lane and a stile a superb view opened out in front of them across a newly cropped field. Continuing downhill through a sheep-filled field and over the next stile they spotted two donkeys in the field, one of which looked very near to giving birth!At the bottom of the field a holly hedge was very carefully negotiated in order to enter a beautul garden belonging to Trehedyn House in the tiny hamlet of Tyrsquon y Pwll, said to be the birthplace of the Welsh hymn writer Thomas Williams, who later moved to Llantwit Major and in  built the Bethesda Chapel there.     Making their way through beautul meadows, they arrived at Lanlay Meadows in Peterston-super-Ely, which are owned by the National Trust. This quiet rural area has been farmed for centuries and the land is untouched by fertilisers, the hedges are left untrimmed, with its twisted oaks the area is rich in animal and plant le and forms part of the Ely Valley Site of Special Scientic Interest.A fairly rare plant Monkshood or Wolfsbane, which also has a number of other names, grows along the riverside and the whole plant, especially the root, is poisonous. The lovely orchard in the meadows provided the group with a great place to enjoy their morning refreshment in the increasingly warm sunshine, before backtracking slightly to follow a grassy path to the river which twists and turns its way along the northern edge of the meadows.Joining part of the Valeways Millennium Heritage Trail and following the river with its bends, nooks and crannies, an unmarked path led them through some rough, muddy ground. Then passing through fields whilst being preceded by a large herd of cattle, they exited just below the village of Pendoylan.Following a surprisingly busy road to re-enter fields on their journey to Caer Wigau Isaf, this th century Tudor manor house is Grade II listed and after a pause to admire the stunning stone and brick-work of the many buildings, they carried on through a small wooded area for the climb up to Lillypot Farm, where the fertile land was acquired by the Bonvillersquos in the th century.Climbing up through meadows they stopped for lunch at the base of their last climb whilst drinking in the stunning views across the Ely Valley. Then continuing their climb, at Lillypot Farm they were greeted by a lovely chestnut pony who was very friendly and eager to have his photo taken with them, before descending through fields near to the defensive ringwork of Y Gaer, an oval enclosure defended by a bank and ditch.Following a path bounded by gardens they arrived back at the extremely busy A to pass through the grounds of St Mary the Virgin Church, which dates from Norman times, but was rebuilt by the Victorians in  and only the tower and chancel arch remain of the original church, before ing to their start point.You can follow the grouprsquos exploits at penarthramblers.wordpress or Facebook article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. The same area has been home to a large lava lake at ious times throughout the volcanorsquos eruptive past.The eruption is not in an area with homes and is entirely contained within Hawaii Volcanoes National Park.ldquoAll signs indicate that it will stay within the crater, said Ken Hon, the USGS scientist in charge of Hawaii Volcano Observatory.ldquoWersquore not seeing any indications that lava is moving into the lower part of the east rt zone where people live. Currently all the activity is within the park. vw,vw,px, px"Webcam footage shows a view of an eruption that has begun in the Halemaumau crater at the summit of Hawaiirsquos Kilauea volcano The volcanorsquos alert level has been raised to ldquowarning and the aviation code changed to red.Earlier, officials said increased earthquake activity and ground swelling had been detected, and at that time raised the alert levels accordingly.Kilauea had a major eruption in  that destroyed more than  homes and displaced thousands of residents. Before that eruption, the volcano had been slowly erupting for decades, but mostly not in densely populated residential areas.Before the major  eruption, Kilauea had been erupting since  and streams of lava occasionally covered rural farms and homes. During that time, the lava sometimes reached the ocean, causing dramatic interactions with the water.Over four months in , Kilauea spewed enough lava to fill , Olympic-sized swimming pools, burying an area more than half the size of Manhattan in up to  feet of now-hardened lava. The molten rock reduced landmarks, streets and neighbourhoods to a vast field of blackened boulders and volcanic shard.     After the  eruption the summit lava lake stopped erupting and for the first time in recorded history began to fill with water, raising concerns about the possibility of an explosive interaction between lava and groundwater. vw,vw,px, px"A view of an eruption that has begun in the Halemaumau crater at the summit of Hawaiirsquos Kilauea volcano The same area of the volcano that began erupting on Wednesday also erupted in December and lasted until May.Hawaii Volcanoes National Park spokesperson Jessica Ferracane told The Associated Press that she had not yet arrived at the park, but that colleagues reported seeing some lava spatter and glow within the summit crater.ldquoHe saw that from Volcano House, which is at least two miles away from the eruption site, so I suspect hellip wersquoll be able to see a pretty glow, and who knows what , she said.The Volcano House is a hotel and restaurant within the national park adjacent to the visitor centre. The park is open to visitors. vw,vw,px, px"Billowing clouds of volcanic gas were seen rising into the air Ms Ferracane said the area that is erupting is not close to where people can hike or drive. Trails downwind from the eruption have been closed for years.ldquoThe park is open and there are no road closures at this time, Ms Ferracane said.Ms Ferracane added that officials are expected tens of thousands of visitors to flock into the park and that people need to be very careful both in terms of natural hazards and Covid-.ldquoThis eruption is going to draw many people to the park, wersquore already seeing people come into the park, drive in after dark tonight, Ms Ferracane said. ldquoReally need people to remember that we are in the middle of a pandemic and they need to stay safe and to keep us safe, too.She said people must maintain six feet of distance and wear masks.ldquoIf yoursquore sick, please donrsquot come.
